intro: Odontites creticus, commonly known as the Cretan toothplant, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in dry, sunny conditions. Odontites creticus is known for its unique leaf structure, which resembles the shape of teeth, giving it its scientific name. It is often found in alpine and subalpine habitats across southern Europe.
